title: What will be the U.S. real quarter-on-quarter GDP growth rate for the second quarter of 2017?
preds:
30 June updates - Atlanta Fed's GDP Now is at 2.7%, down from last week's 2.9, while the New York Fed's Nowcast remains at 1.9%.
https://www.fxstreet.com/news/atlanta-fed-gdpnow-model-forecast-for-real-gdp-growth-q2-of-2017-is-27-201706301452
https://www.newyorkfed.org/research/policy/nowcast

he International Monetary Fund revised its 2017 gross domestic product (GDP) growth forecast for the US downward from 2.3 per cent to 2.1 per cent, citing the Trump administration's inability to implement its economic policies. The IMF on Tuesday also cut its forecast for 2018 US GDP growth to 2.1 per cent from 2.5 per cent. 
http://economictimes.indiatimes.com/news/international/business/imf-cuts-2017-economic-growth-forecast-for-us/articleshow/59346342.cms Problem is extrapolating from yearly to quarterly gdp figures, since quarterlies are usually far more volatile.
Evidence suggests that the economy continues to grow and the forecast is not as gloomy as some predict.

From my reading from all sides, this seems to be a consensus.  Certainly won't get close to 3   to 4% predicted by this administration.  3rd Q might get close.  But so many uncertainties coming from Washington that the only people bullish about the economy are in the stock market, not the actually real economy;  jobs, salary upticks, infrastructure.  Also, with the policies from the White House, i.e. immigration, travel ban, trade, health care, tax breaks - all going to be a mass confusion and repress real growth.

Quarterly data: Real gross domestic product (GDP) increased at an annual rate of 1.2 percent in the first quarter of 2017, according to the "second" estimate released by the Bureau of Economic Analysis. In the fourth quarter, real GDP increased 2.1 percent.
The US economy expanded an annualized 1.2 percent on quarter in the first three months of 2017, better than the advance estimate of 0.7 percent growth and beating market expectations of 0.9 percent, figures from the second estimate showed. It is the lowest growth rate in a year, better than the weakest first-quarter growth in three years initially estimated.
Upping category 3 slightly. It is likely that probability distribution max is somewhere around 2%. Tough to determine if it's gonna go above or below. GJO consensus is way above though. :)

The New York Fed Staff Nowcast stands at 1.9% for 2017:Q2
https://www.newyorkfed.org/research/policy/nowcast St. Louis Fed Economic News Index: Real GDP Nowcast
Q2 2017: 2.32
https://fred.stlouisfed.org/series/STLENI Latest forecast: 2.9 percent — June 16, 2017
https://www.frbatlanta.org/cqer/research/gdpnow.aspx
GDP Atlanta FED expectations are now close to 3%
Revised upward a bit to reflect the Fed's data reading.

Increasing probability of between 2 and 3 based on Atlanta Fed's and NY Fed's latest forecasts.
http://www.barrons.com/articles/second-quarter-gdp-estimates-fall-1497651394
Going Off of WSJ Projected Q2 2017 GDP Growth of 3%: http://projects.wsj.com/econforecast/#ind=gdp&r=20  •	They suspect a rebound from Q1 projection of 1.2%.
Input by Bloomberg TV Guests of financial institutions comments to me by about minimum 1h TV time per day.

Increased 2nd category 10% and lowered 3rd by 10%. The Atlanta FED GDP projection 1.7-2.1 as of 3-15-17. The CBO projection is 1.7 thru 2020. Lowering on reading articles on Business Insider and Barry Ritholtz about how how the FED consistently overestimates GDP. Generally CBO forecasts are more accurate. Also projections partially based on Pres. Trumps tax cuts and deregulation and that seems stalled at this point.

If you look at how Q1 forecasts developed, the Atlanta model estimates started high, but by the middle of March had essentially converged toward the advanced estimate growth number (0.7%). In contrast, the NY Fed model estimate stayed high (2.9%) until the release of the advanced estimate in late April. Based on this, I give higher weight to the Atlanta model, but both models now point to the 2-3% range. Given the overprediction of the NY Fed model, I also give some probability to the 1-2% bucket.
Looks like it's hovering just above 2% based on recent projections. We'll see how the last month plays out.

Quarterly data: Real gross domestic product (GDP) increased at an annual rate of 1.2 percent in the first quarter of 2017, according to the "second" estimate released by the Bureau of Economic Analysis. In the fourth quarter, real GDP increased 2.1 percent.
New York Fed's Nowcast is at 2.3% this week, Atlanta Fed's GDP Now is at 3.0%

Atlanta Fed: "Latest forecast: 3.0 percent — June 9, 2017 The GDPNow model forecast for real GDP growth (seasonally adjusted annual rate) in the second quarter of 2017 is 3.0 percent on June 9, down from 3.4 percent on June 2. The forecast for second-quarter real GDP growth fell from 3.4 percent to 3.1 percent on June 5 after the U.S. Census Bureau's manufacturing report and the incorporation of motor vehicle sales estimates released by the U.S. Bureau of Economic Analysis on the prior business day."
Goldman cuts Q2 GDP to 2.3% from 2.4% after decline in wholesale inventories
Trum news of Paris agreement & news combined with gulf leaders against Qatar
Goldman cuts Q2 GDP estimate to 2.4% from 2.5% on weaker-than-expected manufacturing inventory growth (I expect GS will cut this forecast a few more times)
I believe the number is going to be very close to 3% - difficult to say which way

https://www.bea.gov/newsreleases/national/gdp/2017/gdp1q17_adv.htm High estimates from the Altanta Fed (for nomial at 3.3-3.5%)- https://www.frbatlanta.org/-/media/documents/cqer/researchcq/gdpnow/RealGDPTrackingSlides.pdf sluggish economy so far https://fred.stlouisfed.org/series/GDPC1

https://www.newyorkfed.org/research/policy/nowcast
https://www.frbatlanta.org/cqer/research/gdpnow.aspx New York Fed's "Nowcast" is currently at 2.2%, whereas the Atlanta Fed's "GDP Now" is at 3,4%. "You pays your money and you takes your choice".
Erratic Q1 factors will unwind in Q2
I think the US economy will do OK, not great, not bad, a solid OK in 2017 in all four quarters, might as well express it. My economic predictions have been excellent for 30+ years.

http://www.bbc.com/news/business-40062278
This may mean something.  Or not.  Stay tuned.

Trumponomics has not kicked in yet, but there are enough good wills and investment starts to flow again. Therefore, GDP growth should not fall below 1%, and a slight chance to get over 3%.  It likely beats the current 2%, but there is some chance it will be slightly below 2%.
Mainly due to Spring effects 2nd quarter growth will pick up, big question is whether is will pass the 3%.

Bumping up probability of 3% or more based on this report from Macroeconomic Advisers that predicts 3.2%.  I'm definitely not an expert in calculating GDP, but the rational of a delayed bump as a consequence of nonfarm inventory investment that kicked off during the first few months of the year of stock market euphoria seems like it  is at least a possibility.
http://www.macroadvisers.com/wp/assets/mgdp052517.pdf Goldman revised estimate down to 2.8%
https://www.streetinsider.com/Analyst+Comments/Goldman+Sachs+Cuts+US+GDP+Outlook+For+Q1+Revision+And+Q2+Following+Weak+Economic+Data/12946451.html

https://www.nytimes.com/2017/05/26/business/economy/economic-growth-gross-domestic-product.html?emc=edit_th_20170527&nl=todaysheadlines&nlid=77825025 Instead of 4.1 percent growth in the second quarter, the Federal Reserve Bank of Atlanta’s widely followed GDPNow model now calls for a 3.7 percent rate. And the New York Fed reduced its rival Nowcasting estimate slightly to 2.1 percent. In March, that forecast stood at 3 percent.
New Q1 numbers say it was 1.2%, better than 0.7% previously reported. Adjusting my forecast accordingly.

Historical data by year and by quarter:  https://www.bea.gov/newsreleases/glance.htm 1st quarter 2017: 0.7 percent
4th quarter 2016: 2.1 percent This from the Bureau of Economic Analysis: "The increase in real GDP in the first quarter reflected positive contributions from nonresidential fixed
investment, exports, residential fixed investment, and personal consumption expenditures (PCE), that
were offset by negative contributions from private inventory investment, state and local government
spending, and federal government spending. Imports, which are a subtraction in the calculation of GDP,
increased. The deceleration in real GDP in the first quarter reflected a deceleration in PCE and downturns in private
inventory investment and in state and local government spending that were partly offset by an upturn in
exports and accelerations in both nonresidential and residential fixed investment." https://www.bea.gov/newsreleases/national/gdp/2017/gdp1q17_adv.htm Trump's budget, if it passes, has such staggering cuts to public goods and programs, a significant effect on GDP is reasonably expected down the line.  Destroying Obamacare alone is expected to have an impact on GDP growth.  How much of those jitters will be felt on the 2nd Quarter numbers?
Based on first quarter growth and current political issues surrounding the U.S. government, it seems unlikely that it will reach even 1% for the second quarter.

Economist Intelligence Unit data May 20: Q1 over Q4=0.7%, forecast for 2017=2.2%.
All economic indicators are positive with substantially full employment, makes me stay near 1%.

Things are slowing down and the magician of the art of the deal cannot get it done, in fact it seems that things are getting affected by the lack of talent and know-how in a negative way.
So I can see, if we get lucky, this year that we'll stay in a narrow range, my best guess is of 1 to 1.5 GDP growth.

It sounds like periods of low growth are more likely to be followed by high-growth, since the previous quarter's GDP isn't as hard to beat. Q1 was a low-growth period, so we're slightly more likely to see high growth in Q2.

The average of all quarterly growth rates has been 2.125 since 2013.  5 of these 16 quarters were less than 1%, so that's 31% of them.
3 of them were 1-2% inclusive, so that's 19% of them. 
3 of them were more than 2% but less than 3%, so that's 19% of them. 
5 were 3% or more, so that's 31% of them.  https://www.bea.gov/newsreleases/national/gdp/2017/pdf/gdp1q17_adv.pdf

Real gross domestic product (GDP) increased at an annual rate of 0.7 percent in the first quarter of 2017, according to the "advance" estimate released by the Bureau of Economic Analysis. In the fourth quarter of 2016, real GDP increased 2.1 percent.
https://www.bea.gov/newsreleases/glance.htm
US Real GDP Growth is at 0.70%, compared to 2.10% last quarter and 0.80% last year. This is lower than the long term average of 3.21%.
https://ycharts.com/indicators/real_gdp_growth

COMMENTS:  If the above are the numbers for Q1 I doubt it would raise much above that in Q2

Q1 estimates are already lackluster at best, and uncertainty is likely to continue as the current administration's issues are prolonged.  It is also likely that a retail (brick and mortar) bubble is, while perhaps not bursting, decreasing with greater rapidity.
Adjusting for the increased expectations of the Atlanta Fed GDP Now and reasonable momentum in the economic data

The economy grew at its slowest rate in three years in quarter 1 (.7%). This can mean two things 1) the economy is slowing, 2) last quarter was an anomaly, so expect some regression to the mean (on top of a small denominator). I am leaning toward the latter, and don't expect the inevitable bombshells from the White House to have any strong effects on GDP for Q2.  The weak Q1 and the noisiness of the data makes a high growth rate somewhat more likely.

Corrected upwards because of optimistic outlooks by Atlanta fed and analysts: http://mobile.reuters.com/article/idUSKCN18C20T
http://www.econotimes.com/US-economic-growth-likely-to-rebound-in-Q2-real-GDP-to-grow-about-225-pct-this-year--Nordea-Bank-706272
http://www.valuewalk.com/2017/05/economists-expect-big-jump-in-2q-gdp-well-see/
It will only rebound slightly in the next quarter. US household debt is up; which will slow GDP growth. Instability in the White House will continue to burden the economy.

http://www.reuters.com/article/us-usa-economy-atlantafed-idUSKCN18C20T Tue May 16, 2017 | 2:35pm EDT
Atlanta Fed raises U.S. second-quarter GDP growth view above 4 percent The U.S. economy is forecast to expand at a 4.1 percent annualized pace in the second quarter following the release of April figures on housing starts and industrial output, the Atlanta Federal Reserve's GDP Now forecast model showed on Tuesday. Domestic factory production increased 1.0 percent last month for its biggest monthly gain in over three years, but housing starts unexpectedly fell 2.6 percent, government data showed on Tuesday. The latest second-quarter gross domestic product estimate was faster than the 3.6 percent reading calculated on May 12, the Atlanta Fed said on its website.
data points are softening, this was not expected by economic 'crowd'.
Companies seem to be investing and think the political landscape is better for business.

Averaging the Goldman 2.9% estimate and the Trading Economics 2.1% estimate as highest probability.
http://www.reuters.com/article/us-usa-economy-goldman-sachs-idUSKBN18527G
http://www.tradingeconomics.com/united-states/gdp-growth Last quarter looks like it will be revised up.
https://www.streetinsider.com/Analyst+Comments/Goldman+Sachs+Cuts+US+GDP+

The first quarter was likely a blip, as many parts of the economy are doing well, and low unemployment will likely lead to continued wage growth.  However, weakness in retail will likely cause some panic and both reduce of those visiting said chains, and cause some panic among retail workers, resulting in them spending less too.

GDP growth has disappointed this year. How badly it will do remains to be seen.
http://www.tradingeconomics.com/united-states/gdp-growth
One should expect a bounce from the low q1 number. Atlanta fed Real GDP now forecasts is at 3.6%. I factor in downside drift on this
http://www.tradingeconomics.com/united-states/gdp-growth  The forecast on this site is for 2.1%
Macroeconomic Advisers currently forecasting 3.8% for Q2.
2017Q1 came in lower than expected. There is some seasonality to quarterly growth -- 2nd & 3rd quarters tend to be stronger.

Advance estimate for Q1 2017 is 0.7% over Q4 2016.  I would expect Q2 to pick up further from Q1 because there appears to be some seasonality in the GDP growth rates. Having said that I remain unconvinced that the US government's policies will stimulate growth in production.  Recent budget announcements do suggest growth for the defense industry but I can't see much more beyond that.

Given Q1 performance, it's likely Q2 will be in the same range based on strength of the USD, employment levels, inflation and energy prices. Getting to 3% near term without a catalyst (stimulus, tax change, reg reform) is impossible.

It is highly unlikely that there will be a less than 1% showing, as this would take a 2008 -2009 level of implosion and nothing suggests that happening at the moment. trends suggest that a second quarter uplift is likely but manufacturing data suggests a slower than predicted =turnaround and voter remorse may now turn into consumer caution.

http://www.reuters.com/article/us-usa-economy-idUSKBN17U0EL
Says here Q1 looks soft.  Widespread--nay, universal--uncertainty about what the Trump administration will get up to in the near term could have any of three effects:  Households and firms could go ahead with whatever they were going to do anyway, because why not; they could sit on their money in order to wait and see whether any clarity emerges; or they could go on a drunken spree of spending and investing so as to stockpile ahead of whatever happens next.  Alas, my available sample of households and firms is not only small but just about equally divided among these options.  This may be a question for which the most successful divination method involves bourbon.

Going a bit more positive after Q1 looks to have been a weak quarter for growth, so plenty of room for improvement.  http://uk.businessinsider.com/us-gdp-preview-q1-2017-2017-4?r=US&IR=T "Also, a delay in tax filings, as well as new measures to combat fraud, meant that many Americans received their tax refunds later than usual. Economists expect that some of the spending with tax-refund money is likely to be pushed out into the second quarter." "In addition, the first quarter has consistently been the softest of the year since 2010. That's partly because winter complicates the seasonal adjustments that go into the data." "We expect faster growth in subsequent quarters to help compensate for the slow start to the year, but we only anticipate full-year 2017 real GDP growth of 2.1%, said Sam Bullard, a senior economist at Wells Fargo."

Frugal U.S. consumers seen holding back first-quarter GDP
Reduced business investment in inventories and government spending cuts also crimped gross domestic product growth. A Reuters survey of economists conducted last week forecast GDP rising at a 1.2 percent annual rate, but many economists lowered their estimates after the government on Thursday released advance reports on the goods trade deficit and inventories in March. The Atlanta Federal Reserve is forecasting the economy growing at only a 0.2 percent rate in the first quarter, which would be the weakest performance in three years. http://www.reuters.com/article/us-usa-economy-idUSKBN17U0EL

Well Q2 growth over the last four years has swung between just under 1% to 4% so there is quite a bit of volatility. However, I assume there won't be growth enhancing measures because congress is reliably useless and I fear trump thinks protectionism is the best way to help the economy, as though he is some sort of 18th century mercantilist.  So right now I think steady state of 2-3% growth unless we get into a trade war.
President Trump comes from an economic background and has kept economic plan on the top of his priorities.
Just looking at the top comments for this one. I know next to nothing about economics.
Should be impact by President Trump desicions
"We are looking at a 3% but we think it could be 5 [percent] or even 6 [percent]. We are going to have growth that will be tremendous." -Wall Street Journal 28 September 2015.

On the fence here.  For now I am assuming that a result just under 2.0% is a bit more likely, but am willing to revise depending on eventual Q1 results, probably apparent end of April (preview number), or end of May (second estimate).

I expect it to be above 2.5% and certainly would not be surprised to see it top 3% if only slightly.  Since this does not appear to be based on final adjusted result but only seasonally adjusted I expect the reported number will be as is very often the case to be on the higher rather than lower final number.  Somewhere between 2.75 and 3.25%

If it is announced at anything less than 4%, the numbers will revert to being fake, according to the White House.  Alternatively, It will be the highest growth figure ever recorded in human history, even if it is .04%.    M. Petits-Doigt will apprise us by Twit of the true situation at 04:00 on about the 5th of July.   Stay tuned.

There is nothing concrete that has been done up till now (health care, tax reform etc) to warrant above 3%. Looking at past quarters there is also no clear pattern and a large range (2014, -1 to 5). I am also out of my range of knowledge so I will start at a position of where things are now while I learn more and wait for Q1 results.

This is a tough one at this point in time, with no reliable figures for Q1 available yet, so bit of a shot in the dark.  Manufacturing figures and demand for durable goods look solid for Q1, meaning they will have to be even more solid in Q2 for a robust q-on-q growth rate. 
https://www.federalreserve.gov/Releases/g17/current/default.htm
https://www.census.gov/manufacturing/m3/adv/pdf/durgd.pdf The PMI shows a downward trend in Q1, with new orders and payrolls growing at a slower pace, which could point to a slower growth rate in Q2. http://www.tradingeconomics.com/united-states/manufacturing-pmi Inflation is also picking up, which will depress real GDP growth.
http://www.usinflationcalculator.com/inflation/current-inflation-rates/

This may not have much to do with "economic plans", https://www.nytimes.com/2017/04/18/world/asia/aircraft-carrier-north-korea-carl-vinson.html?smid=fb-share&_r=0
but if errors as substantial are made on other as important issues, I have little faith that "Trump's economic plans aim to return the U.S. to 4 percent annual economic growth" will be met.

Based on the below, and the longer trend lines, probably between 2-3%. We'll have a better gauge when the official Q1 numbers come out at the end of April. http://www.tradingeconomics.com/united-states/gdp-growth/forecast
http://www.kiplinger.com/article/business/T019-C000-S010-gdp-growth-rate-and-forecast.html
